He contrasts the temporary legal washings of the Mosaic law with the eternal, blood-based purification made possible through Christ's sacrificial death. For Calvin, this "fountain" symbolizes the spiritual rebirth where sin and uncleanness are remitted by Christ's blood—no longer requiring ritual purification but direct cleansing through the Holy Spirit's work. Theologically, Calvin stresses that this promise reveals God's active mercy toward the repentant, even those who have "pierced" Him through sin, demonstrating that true repentance generates tangible restoration. Practically, this calls believers to embrace genuine sorrow for sin that leads to Christ, rather than superficial remorse. Calvin underscores that the fountain's abundance signifies God's grace is now accessible to all who turn to Him, dissolving the barriers of sin that once separated people from divine fellowship. This Christ-centered understanding transforms the prophecy: the "uncleanness" addressed is not merely ritual defilement but the spiritual corruption of humanity, resolved through Christ's atoning work. For modern readers, Calvin's insight remains vital—repentance must be rooted in the reality of Christ's blood, not human efforts, enabling believers to approach God with confidence and purity. This promise continues to challenge us to seek true cleansing in Christ, not ritualistic observance, fostering a community where sin's consequences are met with divine restoration. (248 words)

Poole's commentary on Zechariah 13 presents a profound Christ-centered vision where the "fountain opened to the house of David and inhabitants of Jerusalem" symbolizes Christ's blood as the ultimate purifying power for sin and uncleanness, transcending ritual washings of the old covenant. He interprets the subsequent passages as depicting Christ's victory over idolatry and false prophecy—where the devil and deceptive spirits are eradicated—while simultaneously revealing Christ's own death as the means of salvation, where a third of people endure severe trials before being redeemed. Poole emphasizes that the "prophet" narrative (v. 3–6) illustrates how false teachers, once corrected through sharp reproof from their own families, can renounce deception and return to honest labor, mirroring Christ's own wounds as a sign of purification through suffering. Theologically, this underscores that true purification comes not through human rituals but through Christ's sacrificial death, which both destroys false systems and offers genuine cleansing. Practically, it calls believers to examine their hearts against false teachings, embrace honest repentance, and trust Christ's blood as the sole source of purification—rejecting idolatry in thought and practice while recognizing that even Christ's wounds, inflicted through human rejection, become evidence of redemption. This passage provides vital hope: Christ's opened fountain invites all, Jewish and Gentile alike, to be washed in His blood, securing a new life free from spiritual defilement through faith in His finished work. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Zechariah 13 presents a profound theological vision of the New Covenant era, emphasizing Christ's central role in fulfilling Old Testament prophecies. Barnes interprets the "fountain opened to the house of David and to the inhabitants of Jerusalem for sin and for uncleanness" as the permanent source of cleansing and forgiveness established through Christ's sacrifice—directly linking it to John 7:37 (the "living water" of the Spirit) and baptismal remission of sins. This fountain represents the enduring grace available to all believers, transcending the temporary ritual washings of the Mosaic law. Barnes further analyzes Zechariah 13:2-3, where God promises to eliminate idolatry and false prophets, highlighting how Christ's ministry eradicates false systems and deceptive teachings. He notes that the removal of idol names (a practice rooted in Exodus and Joshua) signifies the total destruction of false worship structures, while the severe consequences for false prophets underscore the New Covenant's emphasis on truth and accountability. Theologically, this passage reveals God's active purification of His people—destroying spiritual corruption and ensuring only authentic prophetic voices remain. Practically, believers are called to actively reject idolatry in modern contexts (like false doctrines or materialism), rigorously discern false teachers, and cultivate familial and communal integrity in faith. Crucially, Barnes connects these themes to Christ's victory: the "fountain" is Christ himself (John 4:14), the "unclean spirit" is Satan's deception, and the eradication of false prophets reflects the Church's ultimate triumph over error through Christ's authority. This commentary thus offers a Christ-centered lens for understanding God's ongoing work of cleansing and truth in the life of the believer. (248 words)

Henry stresses that Matthew Henry's commentary on Zechariah 14 presents a dual vision: a future divine judgment on unrepentant nations culminating in Christ's triumphant return, and a profound hope for the church's ultimate restoration. The passage's imagery—particularly the Mount of Olives splitting (v.4), the valley of escape (v.5), and the living waters flowing from Jerusalem (v.8)—functions symbolically to reveal Christ's active presence at the end of history. Henry emphasizes that this chapter points not to literal future events but to Christ's victory over sin and death, where the "one day known to the LORD" (v.7) signifies the definitive moment when Christ establishes his eternal kingdom. Theologically, this underscores God's sovereignty over all nations and the promise of a purified church where holiness permeates every aspect of life, as seen in the command that "every pot in Jerusalem and in Judah shall be holiness unto the LORD" (v.21). Practically, Henry urges believers to live in daily obedience, recognizing that Christ's return brings both judgment on the wicked and the promise of abundant spiritual renewal. This calls Christians to cultivate genuine worship—not as a once-a-year ritual but as a constant, living devotion, where every action reflects Christ's kingship. The commentary's strongest application lies in its warning against spiritual complacency: those who neglect Christ's presence will face drought (v.17-19), while those who actively embrace his kingdom find enduring provision and holiness. Ultimately, Zechariah 14 reveals that true discipleship involves aligning life with Christ's return, where even the smallest acts of worship become expressions of the holy kingdom now present within believers.

John Calvin interprets Zechariah 14:1-2 as a profound warning of imminent divine judgment upon Jerusalem, not merely a future end-time event but a fulfillment of God's justice against the unprepared Jewish community who had returned to their land with misplaced confidence. Calvin emphasizes that the "day of the Lord" here signifies God's sovereign authority, where the city's spoils would be ruthlessly divided among enemies—highlighting the brutality of divine retribution against those who persistently reject God's guidance. Theologically, Calvin stresses that this calamity arises not from human error or chance but directly from God's purpose, designed to prevent complacency and force the faithful to confront their need for divine reliance. Practically, this commentary urges believers to endure present trials with steadfast hope, recognizing that God's judgments, though severe, are just and purposeful, not random. Crucially, Calvin connects this prophecy to Christ: the "residue of the people" who survive signifies the New Covenant remnant preserved through Christ's atoning work, contrasting the temporary earthly judgments with eternal salvation. This foreshadows Christ's ultimate judgment where the faithful, redeemed by grace, will be preserved despite the destruction of the false religious system—affirming that God's promise of a lasting church endures beyond temporal catastrophe, calling believers to trust in Christ's victory rather than worldly security. (248 words)

Matthew Poole interprets Zechariah 14 as a prophetic vision revealing the future judgment on Jerusalem followed by divine deliverance, with profound Christological significance. He emphasizes that the "day of the LORD" foretold here is not merely historical destruction but a divine judgment preceding Christ's final return, where God's active intervention rescues his people from national calamity. Poole's key theological insight lies in his metaphor of the Mount of Olives cleaving to form a valley—symbolizing how Christ, as the "Lord who goes forth to fight," will remove all obstacles to protect his church. This imagery points to the eternal security of the true Jerusalem (the Church), contrasting the doomed physical city with the enduring spiritual community where Christ's presence ensures deliverance. Practically, Poole's commentary urges believers to find refuge in Christ's nearness during present trials, understanding that God's faithfulness to his covenant promises—like the "remnant turning to the Lord"—guarantees protection when we flee to him in spiritual warfare. The prophecy's ultimate Christ connection reveals that Christ himself is the "remnant" who will stand at the center of God's final judgment and restoration, transforming the "plague of Jerusalem's enemies" into the triumph of his kingdom. Thus, believers are called to trust in Christ's return and active care, knowing that the valley he creates for his people is not a place of fear but of divine safety, where the true church remains unshaken by the world's conflicts. (248 words)

Barnes emphasizes that Zechariah 14 presents a future end-time prophecy, not a literal fulfillment in past historical events like Antiochus Epiphanes or Roman destruction, though partial echoes exist. Theologically, this chapter reveals God's sovereign judgment as the central theme: the "day of the Lord" signifies Christ's return when He personally intervenes to defeat all opposition, culminating in the final battle where He "goes forth" to conquer nations—mirroring His triumph over Pharaoh and His role as the ultimate warrior for His people. Barnes connects this prophecy to Christ's dual nature: the "spoils" divided in Jerusalem reflect the ultimate defeat of evil, while the "remnant spared" points to God's promise of a faithful church preserved through Christ's victory. Practically, believers must understand that God's judgment is both inevitable and just, yet His sovereignty ensures a remnant's protection. This calls for vigilance against false interpretations that minimize divine sovereignty, fostering hope that Christ's return will purify and protect His people from the final rebellion of antichrist. The commentary underscores that Zechariah 14's "day of the Lord" is Christ's coming judgment, where He alone acts as judge and redeemer, not human forces. Thus, Christians should live with confidence in Christ's victory, recognizing that His coming will divide the spoils of sin and secure the faithful, urging them to prepare for His return by living righteously and trusting in His promised protection. (248 words)
